Name: Dublin Castle

Locations.Name: Dublin Castle (DEMO)
Locations.Subtitle: Testing a Location Upload
Locations.AboutText: This is the demonstration trail for the final delivery of the Virtual Historic Dublin Cities project SBIR project response from this great adventure ltd.

Storys.Title: January 16th 1922
Storys.ContentText:
On this day in 1922, Michael Collins, the Chairman (Prime Minister) of the Provisional Government of Ireland created under the Anglo-Irish Treaty, accepted control of Dublin Castle from Lord Lieutenant FitzAlan. 

The turnover symbolised the end of British rule in Ireland, even though the Irish Free State would remain part of the Commonwealth until 1949 and the six counties still remain under British rule. 

When Collins arrived at Dublin Castle Lord Lieutenant FitzAlan reportedly said, “you are seven minutes late, Mr. Collins” to which Collins replied “Blasted, you’ve been here seven centuries, what difference does seven minutes make now that you’re leaving.”

Storys.Title: A life on show
Storys.ContentText:
The Upper Courtyard has for centuries been used as a place to show off.

For Georgrian ladies and gents it was all about dinners and balls, wearing the finest fashions and being seen by your peers.

Under British rule, this place was a parade ground, a stage upon which to showcase the military might of empire.

In more recent times, it has seen major public gatherings to celebrate events of national importance, such as announcing the outcome of Ireland's referendum over same sex marriage.
